title: Scientists Find the Pitter Patter of Neanderthal Feet
text:
Tracing steps through sands of time, scientists have uncovered hundreds of footprints left by Neanderthal children, adolescents and adults as they walked the ancient wind-swept dunes of coastal Normandy in France, a new study says.

Left by up to a dozen or so members of the extinct human species, the 80,000-year-old impressions are the largest known collection of Neanderthal tracks, documenting the movements of a group in an era when they were the only human kind in Western Europe, said scientists at the National Museum of Natural History in Paris. They published their analysis of the footprints on Monday in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

Footprints are scarce in the human fossil record and experts in human origins value them because they are a signature of movement and behavior. “The footprints represent a snapshot of the life of Neanderthals,” said paleoanthropologist Jeremy Duveau at the museum in Paris, who led the research team.

One of the 257 Neanderthal footprints found buried under a seaside creek bottom at Le Rozel. Photo: Dominique Cliquet

Based on the size of the imprints, most of them were likely made by children, the youngest perhaps between two and four years old, the scientists said. The smallest footprints measured 4.4 inches long, big enough to fit a modern size 4 shoe suitable for a toddler. The largest were more adult, measuring 11 inches or so.

They hint at how Neanderthals might have supervised their young.

“I loved this image of a prehistoric day care—a couple of adults and trailing behind them are all these kids,” said paleoanthropologist Jeremy DeSilva at Dartmouth College, who studies the evolution of walking. He wasn’t involved in the project. “This is some beautiful evidence that children were being watched after by their parents and others.”

The researchers also found eight handprints imprinted in the hardened fine-grained sand. Those are the only known direct imprints of Neanderthal hands, the scientists said. Images of hands believed to have been painted by Neanderthals were found last year in Spain stenciled alongside 65,000-year-old cave art.

The sand prints were found buried under a seaside creek bottom between the beach and a cliff at Le Rozel in Normandy, about 16 miles from Cherbourg, where French anthropologists have been excavating since 2012. Between 70,000 and 115,000 years ago, the area was a broad stretch of sand dunes.

In all, the scientists found 257 footprints preserved in several layers of sediments, indicating the site had been used off and on for many years. Windblown grit had rapidly covered and preserved the impressions left by feet in sandy mud, the scientists said.

“When I saw the numbers involved here—257 Neanderthal footprints—my jaw hit the floor,” said Dr. DeSilva at Dartmouth. Until now, only a few prehistoric footprints found in Europe have been reliably identified as Neanderthal, he said.

In and around the trackways, the researchers also unearthed flint blades, scraping tools, hearths, and 8,000 animal bones. They didn’t, however, find any fossil human remains, complicating their effort to identify which early species had walked there.

Dozens of the tracks showed clear impressions of a well-rounded heel and individual toes, the scientists said. Generally, the footprints were broader than those typically left by modern humans, the scientists said.

Based on the length and width of various tracks, the researchers estimated that the individuals ranged from about two feet (66 cm) tall to about 6 feet (189.2 cm) tall. More than half of them were less than 4 feet 2 inches tall (130 cm).

Based on anatomy, the antiquity of the site and the style of stone tools at the site, the researchers concluded they could only have been made by Neanderthals.

“We can conclude the group was composed of a majority of children,” said Dr. Duveau. “It is difficult to say it is a family group because we don’t have genetic data.”
